Home


To simulate projectile motion, we need to understand the basic physics principles behind it. When an object is launched with an initial velocity \( v_0 \) at an angle \( \theta \) from the horizontal, its motion can be split into two components: - Horizontal motion: at a constant velocity. - Vertical motion: under constant acceleration due to gravity \( g \). The horizontal displacement \( x \) and the vertical displacement \( y \) as functions of time \( t \) are given by the following equations: \[ x(t) = v_0 \cos(\theta) \cdot t \tag{1} \] \[ y(t) = v_0 \sin(\theta) \cdot t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \tag{2} \] Here, \( g \) is the acceleration due to gravity, which is approximately \( 9.81 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) near the Earth's surface. To calculate the time of flight, we use the fact that the vertical displacement becomes zero when the projectile hits the ground again. Setting \( y(t) = 0 \), we can solve for \( t \). The total time of flight is: \[ t_{\text{flight}} = \frac{2 v_0 \sin(\theta)}{g} \tag{3} \] The maximum height reached by the projectile occurs at \( t = \frac{v_0 \sin(\theta)}{g} \) and is given by: \[ h_{\text{max}} = \frac{v_0^2 \sin^2(\theta)}{2g} \tag{4} \] The horizontal range of the projectile, or how far it travels before hitting the ground, is: \[ R = \frac{v_0^2 \sin(2\theta)}{g} \tag{5} \] By plugging in the values for the initial velocity \( v_0 \) and angle \( \theta \), we can compute the time of flight, maximum height, and range for any projectile. Try launching the projectile with different velocities and angles to see how it affects the motion!
